topics.title: Atomic structure and the periodic table

foundation_content.content: All substances are made of atoms. An atom is the smallest part of an element that can exist.
Atoms of each element are represented by a chemical symbol (e.g., O for oxygen, Na for sodium).
Compounds are formed from elements by chemical reactions and contain two or more elements chemically combined in fixed proportions.
Chemical reactions can be represented by word equations.
Write formulae and balanced chemical equations for reactions in the specification.

higher_content.content: Write balanced half equations and ionic equations where appropriate.

foundation_content.content: A mixture consists of two or more elements or compounds not chemically combined together.
Mixtures can be separated by physical processes: filtration, crystallisation, simple distillation, fractional distillation and chromatography.

subsections.title: The development of the model of the atom

foundation_content.content: The plum pudding model suggested the atom is a ball of positive charge with negative electrons embedded in it.
The nuclear model shows mass concentrated at the centre (nucleus) which is positively charged, with electrons orbiting at specific distances.
The positive charge of the nucleus is subdivided into protons, each with the same amount of positive charge.
James Chadwick provided evidence for the existence of neutrons within the nucleus.

subsections.title: Relative electrical charges of subatomic particles

foundation_content.content: Protons have a relative charge of +1.
Neutrons have a relative charge of 0.
Electrons have a relative charge of -1.
In an atom, the number of electrons equals the number of protons, so atoms have no overall electrical charge.
The atomic number is the number of protons in an atom of an element.
Atoms have a radius of about 0.1 nm (1 x 10^-10 m).
The radius of a nucleus is less than 1/10,000 of the atom (about 1 x 10^-14 m).
Almost all of the mass of an atom is in the nucleus.
Protons have a relative mass of 1.
Neutrons have a relative mass of 1.
Electrons have a very small relative mass.
The mass number is the sum of protons and neutrons in an atom.
Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.
Calculate the numbers of protons, neutrons and electrons in an atom or ion, given its atomic number and mass number.
The relative atomic mass of an element is an average value that takes account of the abundance of the isotopes of the element.
Calculate the relative atomic mass of an element given the percentage abundance of its isotopes.
Electrons occupy the lowest available energy levels (innermost shells).
Electronic structure can be represented by numbers (e.g., 2,8,1 for sodium) or diagrams.
Represent the electronic structures of the first twenty elements of the periodic table.

subsections.title: Conservation of mass and balanced equations

foundation_content.content: The law of conservation of mass states that no atoms are lost or made during a chemical reaction.
The mass of products equals the mass of reactants.

higher_content.content: Calculate masses of reactants and products from balanced equations when given the mass of one substance (including limiting reactant scenarios).

foundation_content.content: Metals can be arranged in order of reactivity in a reactivity series.
A more reactive metal can displace a less reactive metal from a compound.

higher_content.content: Explain how the method of extraction of a metal is related to its position in the reactivity series, including reduction with carbon.

foundation_content.content: Acids are substances that produce hydrogen ions (H+) in aqueous solution.
Alkalis are bases that dissolve in water to produce hydroxide ions (OH-).
Neutralisation reactions between acids and bases produce salt and water.
The pH scale measures how acidic or alkaline a solution is (0-14).

higher_content.content: Distinguish between strong and weak acids in terms of degree of ionisation.
Explain that as pH decreases by one unit, the hydrogen ion concentration increases by a factor of 10.

foundation_content.content: Electrolysis is the decomposition of a compound using electricity.
During electrolysis, ions move to the electrodes where they are discharged to produce elements.

higher_content.content: Write half equations for the reactions occurring at electrodes during electrolysis.
Predict the products of electrolysis of molten salts and aqueous solutions.

foundation_content.content: An exothermic reaction transfers energy to the surroundings (temperature increase).
An endothermic reaction takes in energy from the surroundings (temperature decrease).
Examples of exothermic reactions include combustion, neutralisation, and oxidation. Examples of endothermic include thermal decomposition.

higher_content.content: Calculate energy changes in reactions using bond energies.
Draw and interpret reaction profiles showing activation energy and overall energy change.

topics.title: The rate and extent of chemical change

foundation_content.content: The rate of a chemical reaction measures how fast reactants are used up or products are formed.
Factors affecting rate include: concentration, temperature, surface area, and catalysts.
Chemical reactions occur when particles collide with sufficient energy.

higher_content.content: Calculate the mean rate of a reaction from given information about quantity of reactant used or product formed and time taken.
Calculate the rate of reaction at a specific time from a graph by drawing a tangent.
Explain the effects of changes in conditions on rate in terms of particles colliding with sufficient energy (activation energy).

foundation_content.content: In a reversible reaction, the products can react to form the original reactants.
In a closed system, a reversible reaction reaches equilibrium when the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate.

higher_content.content: Predict the effect of changing conditions (concentration, temperature, pressure) on the position of equilibrium using Le Chatelier's principle.

foundation_content.content: Hydrocarbons are compounds containing hydrogen and carbon only.
Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2.
Alkenes are unsaturated hydrocarbons containing a C=C double bond.
A pure substance consists of only one element or compound.
A formulation is a mixture designed to produce a useful product (e.g., paint, medicines).
Chromatography can be used to separate and identify mixtures.

higher_content.content: Calculate Rf values and use them to identify substances: Rf = distance moved by substance / distance moved by solvent.

foundation_content.content: Test for hydrogen: burns with a squeaky pop.
Test for oxygen: relights a glowing splint.
Test for carbon dioxide: turns limewater milky/cloudy.
Test for chlorine: bleaches damp litmus paper.

subsections.title: The composition and evolution of the Earth's atmosphere

foundation_content.content: The Earth's atmosphere today contains approximately 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, and small amounts of other gases including carbon dioxide, water vapour and noble gases.
The Earth's early atmosphere was formed by volcanic activity and may have been similar to the atmospheres of Mars and Venus today (mainly carbon dioxide with little or no oxygen).
Greenhouse gases in the atmosphere maintain temperatures on Earth high enough to support life.
Greenhouse gases include carbon dioxide, methane and water vapour.
Humans use resources from the Earth for warmth, shelter, food and transport.
Sustainable development meets the needs of current generations without compromising future generations.
Potable water is water that is safe to drink (has acceptably low levels of dissolved salts and microbes).
Water treatment includes filtration, sedimentation and chlorination/UV treatment to kill microbes.

higher_content.content: Describe and evaluate methods of desalination (distillation and reverse osmosis).

foundation_content.content: Life cycle assessment (LCA) evaluates the environmental impact of a product through its lifetime.
Recycling conserves resources and reduces waste.

higher_content.content: Carry out a life cycle assessment including: extraction of raw materials, manufacture, use, and disposal.
